posts.title: CSS at Scale With StyleX
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Build a large enough website with a large enough codebase, and you‚Äôll eventually find that CSS presents challenges at scale. It‚Äôs no different at Meta, which is why we open-sourced StyleX, a solution for CSS at scale. StyleX combines the ergonomics of CSS-in-JS with the performance of static CSS. It allows atomic styling of components while deduplicating definitions to reduce bundle size and exposes a simple API for developers.
StyleX has become the standard at companies like Figma and Snowflake. Here at Meta, it‚Äôs the standard styling system across Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, Messenger, and Threads.
On this episode of the Meta Tech Podcast, meet Melissa, a software engineer at Meta and one of StyleX‚Äôs maintainers. ¬†Pascal Hartig talks to her about all things StyleX‚Äîits origins, how open source has been a force multiplier for the project, and what it‚Äôs like interacting with large companies across the industry as they‚Äôve adopted StyleX.

Download or listen to the episode below:

You can also find the episode wherever you get your podcasts, including:
Spotify
Apple Podcasts
Pocket Casts
The¬†Meta Tech Podcast¬†is a podcast, brought to you by Meta, where we highlight the work Meta‚Äôs engineers are doing at every level ‚Äì from low-level frameworks to end-user features.
Send us feedback on¬†Instagram,¬†Threads, or¬†X.
And if you‚Äôre interested in learning more about career opportunities at Meta visit the¬†Meta Careers¬†page.
The post CSS at Scale With StyleX appeared first on Engineering at Meta.

posts.title: Advent of Code 2025 in Kotlin: Puzzles, Prizes, and Community
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Thank you to everyone who participated in Advent of Code 2025 in Kotlin! Once again, it was a joy to see so many of you sharing solutions, cheering each other on in Slack, and keeping the holiday coding spirit alive.
This year, we kicked things off with five days of livestreams on December 1‚Äì5, with Sebastian Aigner and fantastic guests solving puzzles live, discussing strategies, and showing off idiomatic Kotlin approaches.
If you missed the streams or want to revisit a clever trick, you can still catch up with the recordings:






Community
The Advent of Code puzzles remain available all year round, and so does the community energy. The #advent-of-code channel in the Kotlinlang Slack was once again full of:
Creative Kotlin snippets
Non-spoiler hints
Lots of encouragement
Whether you took part in discussions every day or just lurked and learned, thank you for making the channel such a friendly, collaborative space.
Join the AoC channel in Slack
Winners
As in previous years, we invited you to solve Advent of Code puzzles in Kotlin, join our Kotlin leaderboards, and share your solutions on GitHub with the aoc-2025-in-kotlin topic for a chance to win special Kotlin prizes.
This year, we‚Äôre celebrating nine winners across three categories: Fastest to Solve, Random, and Community.
Fastest to Solve
These three contestants topped the combined Kotlin leaderboards, consistently solving the puzzles at impressive speed:
Kroppeb
AndrejStratmann
770grappenmaker





Congratulations on those lightning-fast stars and Kotlin-powered solutions!
Random winners
To give everyone a chance regardless of speed, we also randomly selected three prize winners from all the participants:
lbcp
FelixDombek
bjdupuis




If you see your name here, keep an eye on your inbox. We‚Äôll be in touch about your prize soon.
Community winners
Finally, Advent of Code in Kotlin wouldn‚Äôt be the same without the people who answer questions, share insights and alternative solutions, help newcomers get started, and keep the #advent-of-code channel buzzing throughout December.
This year, we‚Äôd like to give a special shout-out to these three community stars:
jakubgwozdz
bj0
ephemient





Thank you for your team spirit in the Kotlin community!
Keep learning and solving
Advent of Code might be over for this year, but the puzzles and the learning opportunities remain. If you‚Äôd like to keep sharpening your skills and prepare for future events, here are some resources:
Advent of Code 2025 in Kotlin YouTube playlist.
Solutions to Advent of Code puzzles from previous years in idiomatic Kotlin.
A tutorial on how to explore and solve programming puzzles using Kotlin Notebooks.




We want to say a huge thank-you, as always, to Eric Wastl and the Advent of Code team for creating such a beloved set of puzzles year after year.
Let‚Äôs keep exploring Kotlin, solving algorithmic challenges, and supporting each other. We hope to see you for the next Advent of Code in Kotlin! üéÑ

posts.creator: Dmitrii Korovin
posts.title: How to Troubleshoot Builds With TeamCity Dashboards
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
This article was brought to you by Damaso Sanoja, draft.dev.
If you‚Äôre spending your mornings debugging Jenkins pipeline failures, waiting for builds that should take minutes but stretch into hours, or scrambling to identify which plugin update broke your deployment process, you‚Äôre not alone. These daily troubleshooting battles with legacy CI/CD systems drain engineering time that could be spent building features and delivering value.
TeamCity‚Äôs built-in health signals help you address these everyday struggles head-on by surfacing the root causes of your pipeline problems before they escalate. Instead of hunting through logs to understand why builds fail, you get clear visibility into success rates, build duration trends, and bottleneck identification. When issues arise, comprehensive test reporting and failure analysis help you pinpoint what broke and why, turning hours of detective work into minutes of targeted fixes.
In this article, you‚Äôll learn how TeamCity‚Äôs monitoring and diagnostic capabilities give you the insights needed to maintain stable and fast pipelines and spend more time on what matters most ‚Äì shipping quality software.
Ensuring stability and quality in every release
Consistently shipping stable, high-quality code is non-negotiable; unstable releases undermine customer trust, inflate support costs, and create compounding technical debt. But how do you know your pipeline is stable and which levers improve quality?
TeamCity‚Äôs Statistics Charts offer precise answers that translate complexity into clarity.
Monitor success rates for continuous stability
Success rate is an important metric of any CI/CD: It tracks the percentage of passing builds over time, spotlighting trends and sudden changes.
High success rates indicate predictable pipelines and effective feedback loops, while dips signal fragility, demanding immediate attention.




Visualize test failures to diagnose quality risks
Failure rates provide additional insight: While the success rate gives you a pass/fail snapshot, overlaying failed test counts helps pinpoint when and how systemic issues emerge, revealing what releases are more problematic.
In the same Statistics tab, toggle Show failed in the Test Count graph to make test failures visible.




Access high-level failure data in seconds
Rapidly spotting patterns, like back-to-back failures, allows for proactive fixes before technical debt accumulates.
Use the Overview tab for a high-level summary of all builds for a project, listed with their statuses, durations, changes, and failure indicators.




Investigate failures with one click
Click into any build for detailed information regarding the status of every step, their duration, code-inspection results, changes in the code, and more:




Follow the evidence: Click the Tests tab to get the full breakdown of which tests failed, whether they‚Äôre new or recurring, and contextual details that guide targeted fixes:




From the Tests tab, you can drill deeper into individual test behavior by accessing the test history page. Click the three-dot menu to the right of any test name to open this view, which reveals patterns in test failures, such as how frequently the test fails, which build agents experience issues, when failures began, and trends over time. This historical perspective helps you distinguish between flaky tests and genuine regressions, making it easier to prioritize fixes based on impact and recurrence.




To complete the feedback loop, the Build Log offers a searchable, chronological trace of every step for uncovering underlying errors and misconfigurations behind failed tests.




From failures to code quality: Tracking what matters
After tracing a failure, comprehensive quality assurance means going beyond green builds to deep code insights. TeamCity‚Äôs Statistics tab offers dedicated charts for Code Inspections and Code Coverage to track technical debt and ensure essential logic is tested. You can also extend TeamCity‚Äôs dashboard by adding custom tabs with your own reports to the build results interface, enabling you to incorporate specialized metrics and third-party analysis tools directly into your workflow.




Clicking any point in the Code Coverage chart brings you to that build‚Äôs Coverage tab. Depending on your configured tool (in this example, coverage.py), you‚Äôll find granular coverage reports here. These insights clarify which parts of your codebase are thoroughly tested versus those at risk of silent failure.




Understanding where failures occur and which code remains untested raises quality, shortens feedback loops, and reduces risk for every subsequent release.
Accelerating delivery: Measuring and improving release velocity
Once stability and quality are established, the next challenge for any engineering team is maximizing how quickly new value reaches users.
TeamCity‚Äôs analytic charts and dashboards surface velocity as a multidimensional flow to help you drive meaningful gains in delivery speed without sacrificing rigor. You can enhance these analytics by reporting custom statistic values using TeamCity service messages directly from your build steps, allowing you to track metrics like code coverage percentages, inspection results, and other team-specific indicators alongside TeamCity‚Äôs built-in measurements.
Monitoring release cadence for continuous value delivery
Every successful production release puts features, fixes, and security improvements directly into the hands of customers. That‚Äôs why tracking how often your CI/CD pipeline ships code is a critical health signal for agility and operational efficiency.
Frequent deployments mean smaller, safer changes and less risk per release.
TeamCity charts like Time Spent in Queue and Build Times help you identify when and how production deployments occur to quickly spot accelerations or slowdowns in delivery cadence.




Shortening cycle time for a faster feedback loop
Speed isn‚Äôt just about shipping more often; it‚Äôs also about reducing the interval between code commit and user impact. This end-to-end cycle time is an important health signal that defines your delivery pipeline‚Äôs efficiency and how quickly improvements make it to production.
TeamCity‚Äôs flexibility allows for custom charts that highlight patterns in end-to-end delivery duration. For instance, you can build an Average Deployment Time graph using the Starting Build on Agent and Finishing Build on Server metrics:




Improving failure response time to minimize impact
The speed at which your team responds to and recovers from production failures is a pivotal indicator of both resilience and operational maturity. TeamCity‚Äôs Time to Fix Tests and detailed build duration analytics show you how quickly errors surface and get resolved so you can quantify the impact of failures and how effectively you recover.




Monitoring build duration for sustainable velocity
Velocity also depends on how little time is wasted in each cycle. Analyzing Build Times and Build Duration by Stage reveals how efficiently your pipeline processes changes to help you maintain momentum and ensure timely deployments.




Diagnosing bottlenecks: Pinpointing and resolving pipeline inefficiencies
While fast delivery accelerates value, a truly effective pipeline depends on quickly surfacing and eliminating waste before slowdowns become systemic. Efficiently diagnosing bottlenecks prevents frustration, boosts developer productivity, and ensures that each iteration is an opportunity for improvement, not an exercise in firefighting.
TeamCity‚Äôs analytics transform this process from guesswork into surgical, data-driven action.
Spotting build spikes with actionable trends
Analyzing build duration trends is one of the most effective ways to identify pipeline inefficiencies. A sudden spike on the Build Times chart instantly highlights a potential issue, whether due to environmental issues, unusually long tests, or integration problems.
For example, you can use the Build Duration by Stage custom chart to pinpoint where in the pipeline bottlenecks occur as soon as unusual patterns emerge.




Investigating test duration: Finding the crawl in your pipeline
Long build times can often be traced back to problematic tests. You can use the Tests tab in any build to check on the status, name, and duration of every test.




If the test duration is abnormally high, you can click on it for a historical trend chart that lets you identify when the test began slowing down and in what context.




Simply click on any test to mute it or assign ownership for further investigation, ensuring accountability and rapid feedback.




Detecting and managing flaky tests automatically
Flaky tests (those that fail unpredictably) can silently degrade confidence in your pipeline and are notoriously difficult to spot through duration analysis alone.
TeamCity proactively flags flaky tests and surfaces them in the dedicated Flaky Tests tab at the project level. Here, you see the test name, failure count, flip rate, and insights into the causes for flakiness that you can act on.




Flaky tests are also prominently flagged in the Overview code inspection section for any failed build. Click into the test entry for a detailed stack trace, or open the error in the Build Log for a deeper dive.




Using test reports for root-cause analysis
Along with flaky test management, TeamCity‚Äôs Tests tab flags these problematic tests and offers a Test History report on clicking. These reports let you compare failure patterns across builds by listing status, duration, build number, changes, agent, and precise timestamps side by side. Additionally, an intuitive history chart enables quick trend analysis.




Conclusion
Moving beyond the daily cycle of troubleshooting builds requires more than patch fixes and workarounds. TeamCity provides the diagnostic clarity you need with built-in health signals that reveal build duration trends, success rate patterns, and failure root causes ‚Äì without having to dive through endless plugin configurations or log files.
Instead of spending hours investigating why builds randomly fail or trying to identify which plugin update broke your deployment chain, TeamCity‚Äôs comprehensive monitoring gives you immediate visibility into pipeline bottlenecks and stability issues. The integrated test reporting eliminates guesswork so you can pinpoint problems quickly and maintain consistent delivery performance.

posts.creator: Innokentii Burtsev
posts.title: Bringing Real Users Into a Product Team Gathering ‚Äì A JetBrains Research Story
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
In product development, assumptions about how people will use a tool don‚Äôt always align with the practical reality.
Last spring, during a gathering of our Junie team, we set out to bridge that gap by trying something new. We ran two hands-on user workshops ‚Äì one online and another in our Belgrade office. For the first time ever, we brought external users directly into an internal event.
Here‚Äôs what happened, what we discovered, and why we think this approach is worth repeating ‚Äì both for us and for other research and product teams.
Why we did it
At JetBrains, user research is a continuous effort. Our UX Research team, part of the larger Strategic Research and Market Intelligence team, conducts studies, surveys, and experiments for multiple products. Usually, our role is to provide synthesized insights to product teams.
This time, however, we wanted to flip the model. Instead of delivering results, we created a space where everyone on the product team ‚Äì developers, designers, and managers ‚Äì could experience first-hand contact with real users.
That kind of direct exposure can help foster empathy and transform abstract feedback into tangible improvements.
Overcoming the challenges
It wasn‚Äôt all smooth sailing:
Recruitment: We had just two weeks to recruit participants and prepare interview guides. We solved it through snowball sampling, reaching out via personal connections.
Rewards: Reward logistics were tricky, as some countries don‚Äôt support common gift card providers.
Training: Many team members had never conducted live interviews before, so we gave them a crash course on user research.
These adjustments proved that meaningful research activities can happen even under tight constraints.
The online sessions
We met with five active users via video to explore how they work with Junie, what tasks it helps them complete, and where they see room for improvement.
After the interviews, the team regrouped to share observations and brainstorm potential roadmap ideas.
In-person workshop¬†
Five small business owners joined us in our Belgrade office.
Each team had 1.5 hours to create a working website using our tool and then present the results.
This ‚Äúbuild together‚Äù format exposed strengths and weaknesses in real-time, with deeper insights often hidden in surveys or retrospective interviews.
üìå Key takeaways
By embedding live user sessions into a team gathering, we:
‚úÖ Gave non-researchers a chance to practice their interviewing and observation skills.
‚úÖ Sparked product discussions grounded in real, shared experiences rather than reports.
‚úÖ Strengthened the connection between roadmap decisions and user needs.
Even a short, structured user research activity during an in-person team workshop or planning session can make feedback tangible, accelerate learning, and increase empathy, proving that UX research doesn‚Äôt have to be separate from everyday product development.
The key is to keep it simple, prepare teams with just enough guidance, and focus on authentic user interaction.
üí¨ Want to take part in future JetBrains research?
Join our research panel to get early access to product experiments, test new features, and share your feedback directly with our teams.
üëâ Sign up here to join the JetBrains Tech Insights Lab

posts.creator: Irina Mariasova
posts.title: Java Annotated Monthly ‚Äì January 2026
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Happy New Year and welcome to the first Java Annotated Monthly of 2026! We hope this year brings fresh ideas, smarter ways to stay productive, and innovation that lasts.
JAM, as always, is your island of stability in the fast-moving tech world, bringing the coolest news and practical tips. This time, we are starting strong with the amazing Neha Sardana as our featured content guest. Let‚Äôs dive in!
Featured Content¬†
Neha Sardana, currently serving as the Vice President and Senior Developer at Morgan Stanley in New York, brings over a decade of experience in the financial services industry across Europe and the US. Apart from her professional commitments, Neha is an active member of the Garden State JUG and NYJavaSIG, where she contributes her expertise in Java technology. As a fervent supporter of open-source software (OSS), she enjoys discussing and writing about everything related to it on her blog.
Hello again, and Happy New Year! I hope you all had a wonderful holiday with your friends and family. I‚Äôve been on parental leave since August with a new baby and a toddler at home ‚Äì¬† I have two under three and life is a mess, of course. With all that going on, I‚Äôve still managed to read a bit about something other than AI, since we seem to be talking about it constantly these days.
Recently, I‚Äôve been digging into Project Valhalla. I keep comparing these features to Scala, which I‚Äôve been using for a while now, and it‚Äôs honestly great to see these ideas finally making their way into the Java ecosystem.
Right now, Java treats almost everything like a heavy object that needs its own ‚ÄúID card‚Äù (identity). Valhalla lets us tell the JVM, ‚ÄúHey, this is just a piece of data, treat it like a primitive.‚Äù It cuts out the memory bloat and makes the cache much happier. Even if you aren‚Äôt writing low-level library code, it‚Äôs a big deal because the frameworks we use every day are going to get a massive performance boost for free. It‚Äôs essentially Java finally admitting that we should be able to write clean code without the ‚Äúobject tax‚Äù dragging everything down.
Valhalla has been in the works forever, but with the recent JEP 401 updates, it‚Äôs finally starting to feel like a real thing we can use rather than just a research project. Between this and Project Loom, it feels like Java is finally growing up and giving us the tools to write idiomatic code without forcing us to trade performance for readability. Even if you never touch a value class yourself, you‚Äôll feel the impact once the collections and libraries we all rely on start getting swapped out under the hood.
Here are some links to get started:
Baeldung: Java Valhalla Project ‚Äì a clear, developer-friendly explanation¬†
Inside Java ‚Äì Valhalla articles & talks ‚Äì deeper technical updates¬†
Valhalla may still be evolving, but understanding what it‚Äôs trying to solve today will make the next generation of Java features feel much less surprising when they arrive.
Java News
All the December Java news is here:
Java News Roundup 1, 2, 3, 4
All Features in Java 26 ‚Äì Inside Java Newscast #102
JEP targeted to JDK 26: 529: Vector API (11th Incubator)
JEP 526 Simplifies Deferred Initialization Ahead of JDK 26
JEP 500: Java to Enforce Strict Final Field Immutability by Restricting Reflection
So Long and Thanks for All the Applets
JEP targeted to JDK 26: 530: Primitive Types in Patterns, instanceof, and switch (4th Preview)
Performance Improvements in JDK 25
Java Tutorials and Tips
Don‚Äôt miss these tutorials and tips for peak Java productivity:
The best way to replace the deprecated GenericGenerator
Java, What‚Äôs Old? Part III: I/O
On the Boundaries of Final
The 5 Knights of the MCP Apocalypse¬†
Nice and Naughty Cases of Pattern Matching
Optimizing MongoDB Queries in Java Applications
Episode 42 ‚ÄúFrom Sumatra to Panama, from Babylon to Valhalla‚Äù with John Rose
Valhalla? Python? Withers? Lombok? ‚Äì Ask the Architects at JavaOne‚Äô25
Quality Outreach Heads-up ‚Äì JDK 26: Jlink Compression Plugin Now Handles -c Option Correctly
Java‚Äôs 2025 in Review ‚Äì Inside Java Newscast #103
Virtual Threads in the Real World: Fast, Robust Java Microservices with Helidon
First Experiments with Java on the LattePanda IOTA: An Alternative to Raspberry Pi?
I Created a Game Using ONLY a Controller (No Keyboard!)

Marit van DijkPiotr Przyby≈Ç ‚Äì Learning modern Java the playful way
Kotlin Corner
Check out the monthly Kotlin highlights:¬†
The Deprecation of K1 Mode

The Ultimate Guide to Successfully Adopting Kotlin in a Java-Dominated Environment¬†
AI¬†
The AI world never stops, so stay up to date with a handpicked set of helpful articles:
AI Agentic Patterns and Anti-Patterns
Defining factors for enterprise AI agents ‚Äì JetBrains @ FC London ‚Äô25
Podcast: Transforming Life Sciences: AI, Vibe Coding, and Drug Development Acceleration
Foojay Podcast #86: Agents, MCP, and Graph Databases: Java Developers Navigate the AI Revolution
Implementing the Interactions API with Antigravity
Article: Where Architects Sit in the Era of AI
My AI Colleague: Claude, the good, the bad, the UglAI¬†
What Actually Is Claude Code‚Äôs Plan Mode?¬†
Languages, Frameworks, Libraries, and Technologies
Spring updates and other tech news are ready to explore:¬†
This Week in Spring 1, 2, 3, 4
This Year in Spring ‚Äì December 30th, 2025
Towards Spring Tools 5 ‚Äì Ready for AI
Spring AI: Mapping LLM Responses to Java Objects

Spring Tools 5.0 released
Modern Bytecode Instrumentation with ByteBuddy ‚Äì Rafael Winterhalter | The Marco Show
Explainable AI Agents: Capture LLM Tool Call Reasoning with Spring AI¬†
¬†A Bootiful Podcast: Spring cofounder Juergen Hoeller on the amazing Spring Framework 7 release¬†
Episode 43 ‚ÄúPredictability or Innovation? Both!‚Äù with Georges Saab
Conferences and Events
Don‚Äôt miss:¬†
jChampionsConference ‚Äì Online, January 22, 23, 26, 27
Culture and Community
Career growth, the developer‚Äôs place in the AI world, and the kind of questions people share over coffee:¬†
Things You Thought You Didn‚Äôt Need To Care About That Have a Big Impact On Your Job
Foojay Podcast #87: The Human Side of Development: Career Growth, Staying Healthy, and Why People Matter More Than AI
A Bootiful Podcast: Nate Schutta the fundamentals of software engineering
How Artificial Intelligence Can Help Us Connect with Customers
Keep earning your title, or it expires
Good Writing
And Finally‚Ä¶
The coolest and most helpful articles from the IntelliJ IDEA team:¬†
The Unified IntelliJ IDEA: More Free Features, a Better Experience, Smoother Flow
Kubernetes Made Simple: A Guide for JVM Developers
IntelliJ IDEA 2025.3 Is Out Now!

Meet the Islands Theme ‚Äì The New Default Look for JetBrains IDEs¬†
That‚Äôs it for today! We‚Äôre always collecting ideas for the next Java Annotated Monthly ‚Äì send us your suggestions via email or X by January 20. Don‚Äôt forget to check out our archive of past JAM issues for any articles you might have missed!

posts.creator: Gerum Haile
posts.title: Pay As a Local
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
How Airbnb rolled out 20+ locally relevant payment methods worldwide in just 14¬†months
By: Gerum Haile, Bo Shi, Yujia Liu, Yanwei Bai, Bo Yuan, Rory MacQueen, Yixia¬†Mao

Across the more than 220 global markets that Airbnb operates in, cards are the primary way that guests pay for stays, experiences, and services. However, to help make our platform accessible to more people, reduce friction at checkout, and drive more adoption, we introduced trusted, locally preferred payment methods‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcalled local payment methods or LPMs. By offering and supporting these payment methods, Airbnb enables guests everywhere to choose what works best for¬†them.
In this blog post, we‚Äôll discuss the implementation details behind our Pay as a Local initiative, which allowed us to launch 20+ local payment methods across multiple markets in just over one¬†year.
LPMs: What they are, why they matter, and our discovery and selection process
Local payment methods go beyond traditional cards and¬†include:

Country or region-specific digital wallets (such as M-Pesa or MTN,¬†MoMo)
Online bank transfers (such as Online Banking Czech, Online Banking Slovakia)
Real-time or instant bank payments (such as PIX,¬†UPI)
Local payment schemes (such as EFTPOS, Cartes Bancaires)

By embracing LPMs, Airbnb helps make travel more inclusive and seamless for people around the world. LPMs help the platform¬†to:

Boost conversion and bookings by offering guests familiar, trusted payment¬†options.
Unlock new markets where credit card usage is low or non-existent.
Build accessibility for guests without credit cards or traditional banking¬†access.

Through our research on local payment methods (LPMs), we identified over 300 unique payment options worldwide. For the initial phase of the LPM initiative, we used a structured qualification framework to select which local payment methods we would support. We evaluated the top 75 travel markets and selected the top one to two payment methods per market‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääexcluding those without a clear travel use case‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand arrived at a shortlist of just over 20 LPMs best suited for integration into our payment platform.
Background on Airbnb‚Äôs payment¬†platform
Airbnb‚Äôs payments platform is designed to decouple payment logic from the core business (i.e., stays, experiences, and services), allowing for greater flexibility and scalability. The platform efficiently coordinates both guest pay-ins and host payouts by working with regulated payment service providers and financial partners.
Beyond payment processing, the system also supports robust payment trust and compliance functions.
Modernization
As part of a multi-year replatforming initiative for our payments architecture called Payments LTA (long-term architecture), we shifted from a monolithic system to a capability-oriented services system structured by domains, using a domain-driven decomposition approach. This modernization approach reduced our time to market, increased reusability and extensibility, and empowered greater team autonomy.
The core payment domain delivers essential capabilities for pay-in, payout, and payment intermediation. It consists of multiple subdomains, including Pay-in, Payout, Transaction Fulfillment, Processing, Wallet & instruments, Ledger, Incentives & Stored Value, Issuing, and Settlement & Reconciliation.
Replatforming as an enabler for local payment method expansion
The processing subdomain enables integration with third-party payment service providers (PSPs) and supports API and file-based vendor integration, as well as switching and routing capabilities. As part of our replatforming initiative, we adopted a connector and plugin-based architecture for onboarding new third-party payment service providers. This strategy has significantly reduced the time required to integrate new PSPs in different markets.
During this replatforming effort, we also introduced Multi-Step Transactions (MST): a processor-agnostic framework that supports payment flows completed across multiple stages. MST defines a PSP-agnostic transaction language to describe the intermediate steps required in a payment, such as submitting supplemental data or handling dynamic interactions. These steps, called Actions, can¬†include:

Redirects
Strong customer authentication (SCA) frictions (challenges, fingerprinting)
Payment method‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääspecific¬†flows

When a PSP indicates that an additional user action is required, its vendor plugin normalizes the request into an ActionPayload and returns it with a transaction intent status of ACTION_REQUIRED. This architecture ensures consistent handling of complex, multi-step payment experiences across diverse PSPs and¬†markets.

LPM integration architecture
While our modernized payment platform laid the foundation for enabling LPMs, these payment methods come with a unique set of challenges. Many local methods require users to complete transactions in third-party wallet apps. This introduces complexity in app switching, session hand-off, and synchronization between Airbnb and external digital¬†wallets.
Each local payment vendor also exposes different APIs and behaviors across charge, refund, and settlement flows, making integration and standardization difficult.
Technical approach
We analyzed the end-to-end behavior of our 20+ LPMs, and identified three foundational payment flows that capture the full spectrum of user and system interactions. By distilling LPM behaviors into these standardized payment flow archetypes, we established a unified framework for integration:

Redirect flow: Guests are redirected to a third-party site or app to complete the payment, then return to Airbnb to finalize their booking (e.g., Naver Pay, GoPay,¬†FPX).
Async flow: Guests complete payment externally after receiving a prompt (such as a QR code or push notification), and Airbnb receives payment confirmation asynchronously via webhooks (e.g., Pix, MB Way,¬†Blik).
Direct flow: Guests enter their payment credentials directly within Airbnb‚Äôs interface, allowing real-time processing similar to traditional card payments (e.g., Carte Bancaires, Apple¬†Pay).

This standardized approach has enabled significant reusability across integrations and substantially reduced the engineering effort required to support new payment¬†methods.
Asynchronous payment orchestration
Since many guests complete payments through external providers, we redesigned our payment orchestration‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbuilding on top of MST‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääto support payment flows that require user actions outside Airbnb (redirect flows and async¬†flows).
For redirect flows, where guests complete the payment on a third-party app or¬†website:

Airbnb‚Äôs payments platform sends a charge request to the local payment vendor, whose response includes a redirectUrl.
Our platform redirects the user to the external app or website to complete the¬†payment.
Once the payment is successfully completed, the user is redirected back to Airbnb with a result token. Airbnb‚Äôs payments platform then uses this token to securely confirm and finalize the payment with the local processor.

For async flows (which typically involve scanning a QR¬†code):

Airbnb‚Äôs payments platform sends a charge request to the local payment vendor, whose response includes a qrCodeData.
The checkout page displays the QR code for the user to scan and complete the payment in their wallet¬†app.
After the payment succeeds, the vendor sends a webhook notification to Airbnb‚Äôs payments platform, which updates the payment status to success and confirms the user‚Äôs¬†order.

Naver Pay: Redirect To Naver Pay¬†Website
Naver Pay is one of the fastest-growing digital payment methods in South Korea. As of early 2025, it has reached over 30.6 million active users, representing approximately 60% of the South Korean population. Enabling Naver Pay in the South Korean market not only helps deliver a more seamless and familiar payment experience for local guests, but also expands Airbnb‚Äôs reach to new users who prefer using Naver Pay as their primary payment¬†method.

Pix: Scan A QR¬†Code
Pix is an instant payment system developed by the Central Bank of Brazil, enabling 24/7 real-time money transfers through methods such as QR codes or Pix keys. Its adoption has been extraordinary‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääby late 2024, more than 76% of Brazil‚Äôs population was using Pix, making it the country‚Äôs most popular payment method, surpassing cash, credit, and debit cards. In 2024 alone, Pix processed over BRL 26.4 trillion (approximately USD 4.6 trillion) in transaction volume, underscoring its pivotal role in Brazil‚Äôs digital payment ecosystem.

Config-driven payment method integration
Airbnb embraced a config-driven approach, powered by a central YAML-based Payment Method Config that acts as a single source of truth for flows, eligibility, input fields, refund rules, and more. Instead of scattering payment method logic across the frontend, backend, and various services, we consolidate all relevant details in this config. Both core payment services and frontend experiences dynamically reference this single source of truth, ensuring consistency for eligibility checks, UI rendering, and business rules. This unified approach dramatically reduces duplication, manual updates, and errors across the stack, making integration and maintenance faster and more reliable.
These configs also drive automated code generation for backend services using code generation tools, producing Java classes, DTOs, enums, schema, and integration scaffolding. As a result, integrating or updating a payment method is largely declarative‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääjust a config change. This streamlines launches from months to weeks and makes ongoing maintenance far¬†simpler.

Payment widget
Our payment widget‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe payment method UI embedded into the checkout page‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääincludes the list of available payment methods and handles the user‚Äôs inputs. Local payment methods often require specialized input forms (such as CPF for Pix) and have unique country/currency eligibility.
Rather than hardcoding forms and rules into the client, we centralize both form-field specification and eligibility checks in the backend. Servers send configuration payloads to clients defining exactly which fields to collect, which validation rules to apply, and which payment options to render. This empowers the frontend to dynamically adapt UI and validation for each payment method, accelerating launches and keeping user experiences fresh without frequent client releases.
For example, Pix in Brazil requires the guest‚Äôs first name, last name, and CPF (tax ID), which we collect and transmit as required to complete the¬†payment.

Below is a diagram illustrating how dynamic payment method configurations are delivered from the backend to the frontend, enabling tailored checkout presentations for each payment¬†method.

Building confidence through better testability
Testing local payment methods can be difficult, because developers often don‚Äôt have access to local wallets. Yet with such a broad range of payment methods and complex flows, comprehensive testing is essential to prevent regressions and ensure seamless functionality.
To address this, we enhanced Airbnb‚Äôs in-house Payment Service Provider (PSP) Emulator, enabling realistic simulation of PSP interactions for both redirect and asynchronous payment methods. The Emulator allows developers to test end-to-end payment scenarios without relying on unstable (or nonexistent) PSP sandboxes. For redirect payments, the Emulator provides a simple UI mirroring PSP acquirer pages, allowing testers to explicitly approve or decline transactions for precise scenario control. For async methods, it returns QR code details and automatically schedules webhook emission tasks upon receiving a /payments request‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädelivering a complete, reliable testing environment across diverse¬†LPMs.

Scaling observability for local payment¬†methods
Maintaining high reliability and availability is critical for Airbnb‚Äôs global payment system. As we expand to support many new local payment methods, we face increasing complexity: greater dependencies on external PSPs and wide variations in payment behaviors. For example, a real-time card payment and a redirect flow like Naver Pay follow completely different technical paths. That diversity makes observability difficult‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa single ‚Äúpayment success rate‚Äù may represent card health well, but say little about an asynchronous LPM. Without proper visibility, regressions can go unnoticed until they affect real users. As dozens of new LPMs go live, observability has become the foundation of reliability.
To address this, we built a centralized monitoring framework that unifies metrics across all layers, from client to PSP. When launching a new LPM, onboarding now requires a single config change; add the method name, and metrics begin streaming automatically:

Client metrics‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääuser-level flow health from¬†clients
Payment backend metrics‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAPI-level metrics for payment¬†flows
PSP metrics‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAPI-level visibility between Airbnb and the¬†PSP
Webhook metrics‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääasync completion status for redirect methods or¬†refunds

We have also standardized the alerting rules across our platform‚Äôs Client, Backend, PSP, and Webhook layers using composite alerts and anomaly detection. Each alert follows a consistent pattern (failure count, rate, time window), e.g., ‚ÄúNaver Pay resume failures > 5 and failure rate > 20% in 30 minutes.‚Äù This design minimizes false positives during low-traffic periods.
This framework scales effectively, providing end-to-end visibility from user click to PSP confirmation. It enables engineers to trace issues in minutes rather than hours, whether those issues were caused by internal changes or external outages. By turning observability into a shared, automated layer, we were able to strengthen the backbone of payment reliability while accelerating the rollout of new LPMs worldwide.
Impact
The Pay as a Local initiative delivered significant business and technical impact:

Meaningful booking uplift: We observed meaningful uplift in bookings and new users in markets where we launched local payment¬†methods
Faster integrations: Reduced integration time significantly through reusable flows and config-driven automation.
Stronger reliability: Improved observability for early outage detection, standardized testing to prevent regressions, and streamlined vendor escalation and on-call processes for global resilience.

Conclusion
Supporting local payment methods helps Airbnb to stay competitive and relevant in the global travel industry. These payment options help improve checkout conversion, drive adoption, and unlock new growth opportunities.
This post outlined how the Airbnb payment platform has evolved to support local payment methods at scale‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthrough asynchronous payment orchestration, config-driven onboarding, centralized observability, and robust testability. Together, these capabilities enable faster integrations, lower maintenance overhead, and offer a more seamless, localized checkout experience for guests worldwide.
As Airbnb continues to expand globally, our payments platform will keep evolving with the same principles of extensibility, reliability, and scalability, ensuring that guests everywhere can pay confidently, using the methods they know and¬†trust.
Acknowledgments
We had many people at Airbnb contributing to this big rearchitecture, but countless thanks to Mini Atwal, Ashish Singla, Musaab At-Taras,Linmin Yang, Yong Rhyu, Yohannes Tsegay, Livar Cunha, Praveena Subrahmanyam, Steve Ickes, Vijaykumar Borkar, Vibhu Ramani, Aashna Jain, Abhishek Ghosh, Abhishek Patel, Adithya Tammavarapu, Akai Hsieh, Akash Budhia, Amar Parkash, Amee Mewada, Ankita Balakrushan Tate, Bharath Kumar Chandramouli, Bo Shi, Bo Yuan. posts.creator: charsyam
posts.title: The era of ‚ÄúKnow-Right‚Äù
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The paradigm of knowledge keeps changing. In the beginning, it was the era of know-how. An individual‚Äôs experience and mastery were the greatest assets, passed down only within a person‚Äôs head or a limited part of an organization. The central question in that era was naturally ‚ÄúHow do we implement this?‚Äù Anyone who could answer that how well was considered a valuable talent and central to work.
Then time passed through the eras of know-what and know-where. As information became easier to find and more high-quality content was created, developers could get a lot of work done simply by searching Google, Stack Overflow, and other sources. Still, the core was know-how ‚Äî because the quality of information was high enough that finding it generally meant it was reliable.
But now that period is becoming the era of ‚ÄúKnow-Right.‚Äù (I‚Äôm not sure if this term really exists or is correct ‚Äî I‚Äôm using it for my own thinking‚Ä¶) Information can be composed easily (I think ‚Äúcomposed‚Äù is more accurate than ‚Äúsearched‚Äù), but now we must verify the reliability of that information. (I‚Äôm using AI assistance to write this, so you should verify this text‚Äôs reliability too.)








Here is a simple summary in a table:






CategoryKnow-howKnow-whatKnow-whereKnow-Right

Focus Era1990s ~ mid-2000slate 2000s ~ mid-2010slate 2010s ~ early 2020smid-2020s ~ (AI era)
Core QuestionHow do I implement this?What should I use?Where is the answer?Is this answer really correct?
Location of KnowledgePersonal experience, internal docsOfficial docs, patterns, best practicesSearch engines, GitHub, Q&AContext, constraints, system understanding
Developer StrengthSkilled hands-on abilityCorrect selection abilityFast searching abilityJudgment, validation, reasoning ability
Learning MethodRepetition, trial-and-errorCase study, comparative learningOptimized search, reference tracingDeep understanding + cross-validation
Cause of FailureLack of experienceWrong choicesCopy-paste lacking contextAccepting without verification
Role of AIAlmost noneReference toolPowerful searcherBoth a subject of judgment and a tool





So how does this change the way we think? For example, think about a simple Redis failure problem:

EraDeveloper Reaction

Know-how‚ÄúWe tuned it this way before and fixed it.‚Äù
Know-what‚ÄúThis issue is caused by KEYS; use SCAN instead.‚Äù
Know-where‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a solution in the official docs and on GitHub.‚Äù
Know-Right‚ÄúFor this workload, SCAN is also risky, and the real problem is the data model.‚Äù





When ChatGPT first came out, things weren‚Äôt this extreme, but the pace of change keeps increasing and the importance of verification is growing. Now the question arises: So how should people prepare for this? Does it necessarily mean that humans must verify everything?
Some people say that, just as we don‚Äôt verify every line of machine code the compiler generates and managers don‚Äôt review every result a team member produces, we should accept a certain level of mistakes. That perspective isn‚Äôt wrong. But still, a single mistake can cause a huge problem ‚Äî and while humans can sometimes understand their own mistakes, AI mistakes might be unknowable. (There is no definitive answer here ‚Äî in a few years this discussion itself might be meaningless.)
One technique to improve LLM reliability is test-time scaling: using a smaller model to evaluate what the larger model generates and filtering out responses below a reliability threshold ‚Äî effectively enhancing performance by throwing out low-confidence results. This resembles using other models (or smaller ones) to verify output, and it shows why evaluating trustworthiness of results is becoming more crucial for people who use this information.
So my question becomes: How should ‚Äúpeople‚Äù be educated in this era? ‚Ä¶I‚Äôll leave that discussion for another time (maybe ‚Äî I‚Äôm still thinking about it).

ÏßÄÏãùÏùò Ìå®Îü¨Îã§ÏûÑÏùÄ Í≥ÑÏÜç Î∞îÎÄåÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Ï¥àÍ∏∞ÏóêÎäî know-how Ïùò ÏãúÎåÄÏòÄÎã§. Í∞úÏù∏Ïùò Í≤ΩÌóòÍ≥º ÏàôÎ†®Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ ÏûêÏÇ∞Ïù¥Í≥†, Ïù¥Îü∞ Í≤ÉÎì§Ïù¥ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏùò Î®∏Î¶øÏÜçÏù¥ÎÇò ÏùºÎ∂Ä Ï°∞ÏßÅÎÇ¥ÏóêÏÑúÎßå Ï†ÑÏàòÎêòÎäî Í∑∏Îü∞ ÏãúÎåÄÏòÄÎã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú know-howÏùò ÏãúÎåÄÏùò ÌïµÏã¨ ÏßàÎ¨∏ÏùÄ ‚ÄúÏñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å‚Äù ÏòÄÎã§. ÎãπÏó∞ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ïù¥ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤åÎ•º Ïûò ÌïòÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ Ïù∏Ïû¨Î°úÏç® Ï§ëÏöîÌïú Í∞ÄÏπòÎ•º Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥†, ÏùºÏùò Ï§ëÏ†êÏóê ÏûàÍ≤å ÎêòÏóàÎã§.
 Í∑∏Îü∞ ÏãúÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Ï†êÏ†ê know-what, know-whereÏùò ÏãúÎåÄÎ•º Í±∞Ï≥êÏò§Í≤å ÎêòÏßÄÎßå, ÏòàÏ†ÑÎ≥¥Îã§ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Ï∞æÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Ïâ¨ÏõåÏßÄÍ≥†, ÎßéÏùÄ ÌÄÑÎ¶¨Ìã∞ ÏûàÎäî Ï†ïÎ≥¥Í∞Ä ÏÉùÏÑ±ÎêòÎ©¥ÏÑú, Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎì§ÏùÄ Íµ¨Í∏Ä, Ïä§ÌÉùÏò§Î≤ÑÌîåÎ°úÏö∞ÎìúÎì±ÏùÑ Í≤ÄÏÉâÌï¥ÏÑú ÎßéÏùÄ ÏùºÏùÑ Ï≤òÎ¶¨Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÎèÑ Í∑∏ ÏïàÏùò ÌïµÏã¨ÏùÄ know-how ÏòÄÎã§. Ï†ïÎ≥¥Îì§Ïùò ÌÄÑÎ¶¨Ìã∞Í∞Ä ÎÜíÏïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê, Ï∞æÍ∏∞Îßå ÌïòÎ©¥ Ïñ¥ÎäêÏ†ïÎèÑÏùò Ïã†Î¢∞ÎèÑÍ∞Ä Î≥¥Ïû•Ïù¥ ÎêòÎçò ÏãúÍ∏∞.
 Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Í∑∏ ÏãúÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Ïù¥Ï†ú ‚ÄúKnow-Right‚Äù Ïùò ÏãúÎåÄÍ∞Ä ÎêòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§.(Know-Right ÎùºÎäî Îã®Ïñ¥Í∞Ä ÏûàÎäîÏßÄ, ÎßûÎäîÏßÄÎäî Ïûò Î™®Î•¥Í≤†ÏßÄÎßå, ÏùºÎã® ÎÇòÎäî ÎÇ¥ ÎßàÏùåÎåÄÎ°ú ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥ÏÑú Ïì∞Í≥† ÏûàÎäî‚Ä¶) Ï†ïÎ≥¥Îäî ÏâΩÍ≤å Íµ¨ÏÑ±Ïù¥ ÎêòÏßÄÎßå(Ï∞æÎäîÎã§Í≥† ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† Íµ¨ÏÑ±ÎêúÎã§ÎùºÎäî Ïö©Ïñ¥Î•º Ïì∞ÎäîÍ≤å ÎßûÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§.) Í∑∏ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Ïùò Ïã†Î¢∞ÎèÑÎ•º Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÌï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäî ÏãúÍ∏∞Ïù¥Îã§.(Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïì∞ÎäîÎç∞ÎèÑ AIÏùò ÎèÑÏõÄÏùÑ ÏñªÍ≥† ÏûàÏúºÎãà, Ïã†Î¢∞ÎèÑÎ•º Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÌïòÏÖîÏïº ÌïúÎã§.)





 ÏùºÎã® Í∞ÑÎã®Ìûà ÌëúÎ°ú Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌïòÎ©¥ Îã§ÏùåÍ≥º Í∞ôÎã§.

Íµ¨Î∂ÑKnow-howKnow-whatKnow-whereKnow-right

Ï§ëÏã¨ ÏãúÍ∏∞1990s ~ 2000s Ï§ëÎ∞ò2000s ÌõÑÎ∞ò ~ 2010s Ï§ëÎ∞ò2010s ÌõÑÎ∞ò ~ 2020s Ï¥à2020s Ï§ëÎ∞ò ~ (AI ÏãúÎåÄ)

Í∞úÎ∞úÏûê Í≤ΩÏüÅÎ†•ÏàôÎ†®Îêú ÏÜêÍ∏∞Ïà†Ïò¨Î∞îÎ•∏ ÏÑ†ÌÉù Îä•Î†•Îπ†Î•∏ ÌÉêÏÉâ Îä•Î†•ÌåêÎã®¬∑Í≤ÄÏ¶ù¬∑Ï∂îÎ°† Îä•Î†•

Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑú ÎìúÎäî Í≥†ÎØºÏùÄ Ïù¥Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Î†áÎã§Î©¥ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏùÄ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ïù¥Î•º ÎåÄÎπÑÌï¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäîÍ∞Ä? Íº≠ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÌï† ÌïÑÏöîÎäî ÏûàÏùÑÍπå?
 ÏùºÎ∂ÄÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥Îñ§ Î∂ÑÎì§ÏùÄ, Ïñ¥Ï∞®Ìîº Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Ïª¥ÌååÏùºÎü¨Í∞Ä ÎßåÎìúÎäî Í∏∞Í≥ÑÏñ¥Î•º Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Í≤ÉÏ≤òÎüº, ÌåÄÏóêÏÑú Îß§ÎãàÏ†ÄÍ∞Ä, ÌåÄÏõêÏùò Î™®Îì† Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ•º ÏßÅÏ†ë Îã§ Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Í≤ÉÏ≤òÎüº, Ïñ¥Îäê Ï†ïÎèÑÏùò Ïã§ÏàòÎäî Ïö©ÎÇ©Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§ÎùºÎäî ÏùòÍ≤¨ÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§. Í∑∏Î†áÏßÄÎßå Ïó¨Ï†ÑÌûà Ïã§Ïàò ÌïòÎÇòÍ∞Ä ÍµâÏû•Ìûà ÌÅ∞ Î¨∏Ï†úÎ•º ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÍ≥†, ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏùò Ïã§ÏàòÎäî Í∑∏ Î¨∏Ï†úÎ•º Ïñ¥ÎäêÏ†ïÎèÑ ÌååÏïÖÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏßÄÎßå, AIÏùò Î¨∏Ï†úÎäî Í∑∏Îü¥ Ïàò ÏóÜÏßÄ ÏïäÎÉêÎùºÎäî ÏùòÍ≤¨ÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§.(Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑú ÎãµÏùÄ ÏóÜÎã§. posts.title: SEOÎäî ÎÅùÎÇ¨Îã§? 2026ÎÖÑ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† ÏÑ±Í≥µ Í≥µÏãù, ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìòï ÏóîÏßÑ ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôî(GEO) ÎßàÏä§ÌÑ∞Ìïò
posts.author: Ïñ¥Îñ§Ïò§ÌõÑÏùò ÌîÑÎ¶¨Ïõ®Ïñ¥ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞
posts.content:
2026ÎÖÑ, ÎîîÏßÄÌÑ∏ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† ÏãúÏû•ÏùÄ Í±∞ÎåÄÌïú Î≥ÄÌôîÏùò Î¨ºÍ≤∞Ïóê Ìú©Ïã∏ÏòÄÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌûà ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÎ•º ÎÇòÏó¥ÌïòÎäî SEO ÏãúÎåÄÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎãå, ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìòï AI Í≤ÄÏÉâ(SGE/CUE)Ïù¥ ÏßÄÎ∞∞ÌïòÎäî GEO(Generative Engine Optimization) ÏãúÎåÄÍ∞Ä ÎèÑÎûòÌñàÏ£†. AIÎäî Îçî Ïù¥ÏÉÅ Îã®ÏàúÌïú ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Ïùò ÏÉùÏ°¥Í≥º ÏàòÏùµÏùÑ Í≤∞Ï†ïÌïòÎäî ÌïµÏã¨ ÌîåÎ†àÏù¥Ïñ¥Í∞Ä ÎêòÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑúÎäî AI Ïä¨Î°≠(AI Slop)Ïùò Ìï®Ï†ïÏùÑ ÌîºÌïòÍ≥†, HIT(Human in the Loop) Ï†ÑÎûµÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Î•º AI ÏãúÎåÄÏùò ÌïµÏã¨ ÏûêÏÇ∞ÏúºÎ°ú ÎßåÎìúÎäî Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÑ Ï†úÏãúÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÏùò Ï¢ÖÎßêÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï†úÎ°ú ÌÅ¥Î¶≠ Í≤ÄÏÉâ, Ïú†ÌäúÎ∏å ÏïåÍ≥†Î¶¨Ï¶òÏùò Î≥ÄÌôî, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïª§ÎÆ§ÎãàÌã∞ Í∏∞Î∞ò ÏàòÏùµÌôîÍπåÏßÄ, ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÎîîÏßÄÌÑ∏ ÏàòÏùµÌôî Í≥µÏãùÏùÑ ÌååÌó§Ï≥ê Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî.

Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂Ñ, 2026ÎÖÑ Î∞îÎ°ú Ïù¥ ÏãúÏ†êÏóêÏÑú ÌòπÏãú Ïú†ÌäúÎ∏åÎÇò Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ ÏàòÏùµÏù¥ Í∞ëÏûêÍ∏∞ 0ÏõêÏù¥ Îê† ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§Îäî ÏÇ¨Ïã§ÏùÑ ÏïåÍ≥† Í≥ÑÏÖ®ÎÇòÏöî? Î¨ºÎ°†, Îã®ÏàúÌûà Í≤ÅÏùÑ Ï£ºÎ†§Îäî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Îäî ÏïÑÎãôÎãàÎã§. Íµ¨Í∏ÄÍ≥º Ïú†ÌäúÎ∏åÏùò ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ AI ÏïåÍ≥†Î¶¨Ï¶òÏù¥ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Î•º ‘AI Ïä§Ìå∏’ÏúºÎ°ú Î∂ÑÎ•òÌïòÎäî ÏàúÍ∞Ñ, Í≥µÎì§Ïó¨ ÎßåÎì† Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏù¥ Í≤ÄÏÉâ Í≤∞Í≥ºÏóêÏÑú ÏÇ¨ÎùºÏ†∏ Î≤ÑÎ¶¥ Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî ÌòÑÏã§Ï†ÅÏù∏ Í≤ΩÍ≥†ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú ÏùºÎ∂Ä Ïú†ÌäúÎ∏å ÏáºÏ∏† Ï±ÑÎÑêÎì§Ïù¥ Ïù¥ÎØ∏ Ïù¥ AI Ïä¨Î°≠(AI Slop)Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Ìï®Ï†ïÏóê Îπ†Ï†∏ Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄÏùÑ Í≤™Í≥† ÏûàÍ≥†Ïöî. Í∑∏Î†áÎã§Î©¥ Ïù¥ Í±∞ÎåÄÌïú Î≥ÄÌôî ÏÜçÏóêÏÑú Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÏÇ¥ÏïÑÎÇ®ÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑÍπåÏöî? Ïù¥ ÏúÑÍ∏∞Î•º Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ Í∏∞ÌöåÎ°ú Î∞îÍæ∏Îäî Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÄ ÏóÜÏùÑÍπåÏöî? ÏßÄÍ∏àÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ 2026ÎÖÑ ÎîîÏßÄÌÑ∏ ÏàòÏùµÌôîÏùò ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í≥µÏãùÏùÑ ÌïòÎÇòÌïòÎÇò ÌååÌó§Ï≥ê Î≥¥Í≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

2026ÎÖÑ, ÎîîÏßÄÌÑ∏ ÏàòÏùµÏùò ÎåÄÍ≤©Î≥Ä: SEOÏóêÏÑú GEOÎ°ú

ÏµúÍ∑º ÏµúÏã† Ïª®ÏÑ§ÌåÖ Î≥¥Í≥†ÏÑúÎì§ÏùÑ Î¶¨ÏÑúÏπòÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ï†ïÎßê ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ ÏÇ¨Ïã§ÏùÑ Íπ®Îã¨ÏïòÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÏùµÌûà ÏïåÎçò Í∏∞Ï°¥Ïùò Í≤ÄÏÉâ Î∞©Ïãù, Ï¶â SEO(Search Engine Optimization) Í≤åÏûÑÏùò Î£∞Ïù¥ ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà Î∞îÎÄåÏóàÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÏïÑÎãà, Î∞îÎÄåÏóàÎã§Í∏∞Î≥¥Îã§Îäî Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî Í±∞Ïùò Ï¢ÖÏ∞©Ïó≠Ïóê ÎèÑÎã¨ÌñàÎã§Í≥† Î≥¥Îäî Í≤å ÎßûÏùÑ Í≤É Í∞ôÏïÑÏöî. Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî GEO(Generative Engine Optimization), Ï¶â ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìòï ÏóîÏßÑ ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôîÎùºÎäî ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í≤åÏûÑÏù¥ ÏãúÏûëÎêú Í±∞Ï£†. Ïù¥ Î≥ÄÌôîÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌûà Í≤ÄÏÉâ ÏïåÍ≥†Î¶¨Ï¶òÏùò ÏóÖÎç∞Ïù¥Ìä∏ ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥ÏÑ†, ÎîîÏßÄÌÑ∏ ÏàòÏùµ ÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥Ñ Ï†ÑÏ≤¥Ïùò ÎåÄÍ≤©Î≥ÄÏùÑ ÏùòÎØ∏Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

Í∑∏Î†áÎã§Î©¥ Ïù¥ AIÍ∞Ä Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÏßÄÎ∞∞ÌïòÎäî ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ìï¥Ïïº ÎÇ¥ Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ÎÇò Ïú†ÌäúÎ∏å Ï±ÑÎÑêÏù¥ ÏïåÍ≥†Î¶¨Ï¶òÏùò Ï≤òÎ≤åÏùÑ ÌîºÌïòÍ≥†, Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ AIÏùò ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏùÑ Î∞õÎäî ÌïµÏã¨ ÏûêÏÇ∞Ïù¥ Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑÍπåÏöî? Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Î™©ÌëúÎäî Î™ÖÌôïÌï©ÎãàÎã§. AIÎ•º Îã®ÏàúÌûà Í∏ÄÏù¥ÎÇò ÏòÅÏÉÅÏùÑ Ï¢Ä Îçî Ìé∏Î¶¨ÌïòÍ≤å ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Ï£ºÎäî ‘ÎèÑÏö∞ÎØ∏’ Ï†ïÎèÑÎ°ú ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Í∞ÄÏû• Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú Ï†ÑÎûµÏ†Å Î¨¥Í∏∞Î°ú ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÎäî Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÑ ÏïåÏïÑÎÇ¥Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Ï£†. Ïù¥Ï†ú AIÎäî ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãå ÌïÑÏàòÏù¥Ïûê, Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú ÌôúÏö©ÌïúÎã§Î©¥ ÏÉÅÏÉÅ Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùò ÏÑ±Í≥ºÎ•º Í∞ÄÏ†∏Îã§Ï§Ñ Ïó¥Ïá†Í∞Ä Îê† Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§.

ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÏùò Ï¢ÖÎßêÍ≥º Ï£ºÏ†ú Í∂åÏúÑÏÑ±Ïùò ÏãúÎåÄ

Í∞ÄÏû• Í∑ºÎ≥∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î≥ÄÌôîÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏßöÍ≥† ÎÑòÏñ¥Í∞ÄÏ£†. Î∞îÎ°ú ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÏùò Ï¢ÖÎßêÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÏòàÏ†ÑÏóêÎäî 'Í∞ïÎÇ®Ïó≠ ÎßõÏßë'Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïì∏ Îïå, Î≥∏Î¨∏Ïóê Ïù¥ Îã®Ïñ¥Î•º Ïä§Î¨¥ Î≤àÏî© Î∞òÎ≥µÌï¥ÏÑú ÎÑ£Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÏùºÏ¢ÖÏùò 'Ï†ïÏÑù'Ï≤òÎüº Ïó¨Í≤®Ï°åÏ£†. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå 2026ÎÖÑ ÌòÑÏû¨, Ïù¥Îü∞ Ï†ÑÎûµÏùÄ Îçî Ïù¥ÏÉÅ ÏïÑÎ¨¥Îü∞ ÏùòÎØ∏Í∞Ä ÏóÜÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏïÑÎãà, Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ Ïñ¥Î∑∞Ïßï(abusing)ÏúºÎ°ú Î∂ÑÎ•òÎêòÏñ¥ Í∞êÏ†ê ÏöîÏù∏Ïù¥ Îê† ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò SGE(Search Generative Experience)ÎÇò ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÏùò CUEÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ ÏÉùÏÑ±Ìòï ÏóîÏßÑÎì§ÏùÄ Ïù¥Ï†ú Îã®Ïñ¥Ïùò Í∞úÏàòÎ•º ÏÑ∏Îäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥, ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Ïùò Î¨∏Îß•Í≥º ÏùòÎèÑÎ•º ÌååÏïÖÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÏßëÏ§ëÌïòÎäî ÌïµÏã¨ÏùÄ Îã® ÌïòÎÇòÏûÖÎãàÎã§. “Ïù¥ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Î•º ÎßåÎì† ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ Ïù¥ Ï£ºÏ†úÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ ÏñºÎßàÎÇò ÍπäÏù¥ ÏûàÎäî ÏßÑÏßú Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÏù∏Í∞Ä?” Î∞îÎ°ú Ïù¥ 'Ï£ºÏ†ú Í∂åÏúÑÏÑ±'ÏùÑ ÌèâÍ∞ÄÌïòÎäî Í±∞Ï£†.

ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏù¥ 'AI ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖ'Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Ï£ºÏ†úÎ°ú Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Î•º Ïö¥ÏòÅÌïúÎã§Í≥† Í∞ÄÏ†ïÌï¥ Î¥ÖÏãúÎã§. Í≥ºÍ±∞ÏóêÎäî Ïù¥ ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÎ•º Ìè¨Ìï®Ìïú Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïó¨Îü¨ Í∞ú Î∞úÌñâÌñàÏùÑ Í±∞ÏòàÏöî. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî Ï†ëÍ∑ºÎ≤ïÏù¥ ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà Îã¨ÎùºÏ†∏Ïïº Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. 'AI ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖÏùò ÎØ∏ÎûòÎäî?', 'AI ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖ Ìà¥ 10Í∞ÄÏßÄ ÎπÑÍµê', 'AI ÎßàÏºÄÌåÖ Ïã§Ìå® ÏÇ¨Î°Ä Î∂ÑÏÑù' Îì± ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ Ïù¥ Ï£ºÏ†úÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ Í∂ÅÍ∏àÌï¥Ìï† ÎßåÌïú 50Í∞ú Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùò ÏÑ∏Î∂Ä ÏßàÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ Í∞ÅÍ∞Å ÍπäÏù¥ ÏûàÎäî ÎãµÎ≥ÄÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÎäî ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† ÌÅ¥Îü¨Ïä§ÌÑ∞(Content Cluster)Î•º Íµ¨Ï∂ïÌï¥Ïïº Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

Ï†ÑÏ≤¥ ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Ïùò 80% Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùÑ ÌïòÎÇòÏùò Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ Ï£ºÏ†úÏóê ÏßëÏ§ëÌï† Îïå, AIÎäî ÎπÑÎ°úÏÜå Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùÑ 'ÎØøÏùÑ ÎßåÌïú Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞Ä'Î°ú Ïù∏ÏãùÌïòÍ≥† Í≤ÄÏÉâ Í≤∞Í≥º ÏÉÅÎã®Ïóê Ï†ÅÍ∑πÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÎÖ∏Ï∂úÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏãúÏûëÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïó¨Îü¨ Ï£ºÏ†úÎ•º ÏñïÍ≤å Îã§Î£®Îäî ÏãúÎåÄÎäî Ïù¥Ï†ú Ï†ïÎßê ÎÅùÎÇ¨Îã§Í≥† Î¥êÎèÑ Î¨¥Î∞©Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

GEO ÏãúÎåÄÏùò ÌïµÏã¨: AIÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌûà ÌÇ§ÏõåÎìúÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎãå, ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†Ïùò Î¨∏Îß•Í≥º ÏûëÏÑ±ÏûêÏùò Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ÏÑ±ÏùÑ ÌèâÍ∞ÄÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÌïòÎÇòÏùò Ï£ºÏ†úÏóê ÍπäÏù¥ ÌååÍ≥†Îì§Ïñ¥ 'Ï£ºÏ†ú Í∂åÏúÑÏÑ±'ÏùÑ ÌôïÎ≥¥ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Ï§ëÏöîÌï¥Ïöî.

Ï†úÎ°ú ÌÅ¥Î¶≠ Í≤ÄÏÉâÍ≥º ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Ìè¨ÏßÄÏÖò Ï†úÎ°ú

Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑú Îçî Ï∂©Í≤©Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÇ¨Ïã§Ïù¥ ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏïÑÎ¨¥Î¶¨ Ïó¥Ïã¨Ìûà ÎÖ∏Î†•Ìï¥ÏÑú Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÎ°ú Ïù∏Ï†ïÎ∞õÏïÑÎèÑ, Ï†ïÏûë ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Î•º ÌÅ¥Î¶≠ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÑ ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í±∞ÏòàÏöî. Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Ïù¥Î•º Ï†úÎ°ú ÌÅ¥Î¶≠ Í≤ÄÏÉâ(Zero-Click Search)Ïù¥ÎùºÍ≥† Î∂ÄÎ¶ÖÎãàÎã§. Îßê Í∑∏ÎåÄÎ°ú Í≤ÄÏÉâ Í≤∞Í≥º ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÏóêÏÑú ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Î°úÏùò ÌÅ¥Î¶≠Ïù¥ Î∞úÏÉùÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî ÌòÑÏÉÅÏù¥Ï£†. ÏµúÏã† Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Ïóê Îî∞Î•¥Î©¥, Îç∞Ïä§ÌÅ¨ÌÜ± Í≤ÄÏÉâÏùò Î¨¥Î†§ 46.5%, Í±∞Ïùò Ï†àÎ∞òÏóê Îã¨ÌïòÎäî ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÎì§Ïù¥ AIÍ∞Ä ÏöîÏïΩÌï¥ Ï§Ä ÎãµÎ≥ÄÎßå Î≥¥Í≥† Í≤ÄÏÉâÏùÑ ÎÅùÎÇ¥Î≤ÑÎ¶∞Îã§Í≥† Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.

Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Î≥ÄÌôîÎ°ú Ïù∏Ìï¥ Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú ÏùºÎ∂Ä Í∏ÄÎ°úÎ≤å Í∏∞ÏóÖÎì§ÏùÄ ÏûêÏó∞ Í≤ÄÏÉâÏùÑ ÌÜµÌïú Î∞©Î¨∏Ïûê ÏàòÍ∞Ä 70%ÏóêÏÑú 80%ÍπåÏßÄ Ìè≠ÎùΩÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÑ ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïñ¥Ï†úÍπåÏßÄ 1Îßå Î™ÖÏù¥ Î∞©Î¨∏ÌïòÎçò Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Ïóê Í∞ëÏûêÍ∏∞ 2Ï≤ú Î™ÖÎßå Îì§Ïñ¥Ïò®Îã§Í≥† ÏÉÅÏÉÅÌï¥ Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî. Ï†ïÎßê ÎÅîÏ∞çÌïú ÏãúÎÇòÎ¶¨Ïò§Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎãê Ïàò ÏóÜÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Îî∞ÎùºÏÑú Ïù¥Ï†ú Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Î™©ÌëúÎäî Îã®ÏàúÌûà 'ÌÅ¥Î¶≠'Ïù¥ ÎêòÏñ¥ÏÑúÎäî Ïïà Îê©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏù¥ AI ÏãúÎåÄÏùò ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏† Ï†ÑÎûµÏùÑ ÏÑ∏Ïö∞Îäî Îç∞ ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÏÖ®Í∏∞Î•º ÏßÑÏã¨ÏúºÎ°ú Î∞îÎûçÎãàÎã§. Í∞êÏÇ¨Ìï©ÎãàÎã§!

posts.content:
ÏàòÎßéÏùÄ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Ïùò ÌôçÏàò ÏÜçÏóêÏÑú ÎÇòÎßåÏùò ÏßÄÏãù Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÎ•º Íµ¨Ï∂ïÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏúºÏã†Í∞ÄÏöî?  AIÏôÄ ÏÉùÏÇ∞ÏÑ± Î∂ÑÏïºÏóê ÍπäÏùÄ Í¥ÄÏã¨ÏùÑ ÏèüÏïÑÏôîÎäîÎç∞Ïöî, ÏÜîÏßÅÌûà Í≥†Î∞±ÌïòÏûêÎ©¥, Ï†ÄÎäî ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑêÎßÅÏùÑ ÏãúÎèÑÌñàÏßÄÎßå Îäò Ïñ¥Î†µÍ≤å ÎäêÍª¥Ï°åÏñ¥Ïöî. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ NotebookLMÏùÑ ÎßåÎÇòÎ©¥ÏÑú Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏù¥ Î∞îÎÄåÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Ìè¨Ïä§Ìä∏ÏóêÏÑú Ï†ÄÎßåÏùò NotebookLM ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑê Íµ¨Ï∂ï Í∞ÄÏù¥ÎìúÎ•º AÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ZÍπåÏßÄ ÏïåÎ†§ÎìúÎ¶¥Í≤åÏöî!

ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑêÎßÅ, Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùÄ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÏãúÎÇòÏöî? Ï†úÍ≤å ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑêÏùÄ Í∑∏Ï†Ä Î∞∞Ïö¥ Í≤ÉÏùÑ Í∏∞Î°ùÌïòÎäî 'Î°úÍ∑∏'Ïóê Í∞ÄÍπåÏõ†ÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ NotebookLMÏùò Ïù∏Í≥µÏßÄÎä• ÎßàÎ≤ïÏùÑ Í≤ΩÌóòÌïòÍ≥† ÎÇòÏÑúÎäî, Ïù¥ Í∞úÎÖêÏù¥ ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà Îã¨ÎùºÏ°åÏñ¥Ïöî. Îã®ÏàúÌûà Í∏∞Î°ùÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥, ÏÉÅÌò∏ÏûëÏö©ÌïòÎäî Í∞ÄÏù¥ÎìúÎ∂ÅÏù¥Ïûê ÍπäÏùÄ ÏÑ±Ï∞∞ÏùÑ Ïù¥ÎÅÑÎäî ÏùºÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî ÏÇ¨Ïã§Ïóê Ï†ïÎßê ÎÜÄÎûêÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Ï≤òÏùåÏóêÎäî Í∑∏Ï†Ä Ïã§Ìóò ÏÇºÏïÑ ÏãúÏûëÌñàÏßÄÎßå, ÏßÄÍ∏àÏùÄ Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌûà Ïù¥Ïñ¥Í∞à Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÏÜåÏ§ëÌïú ÏäµÍ¥ÄÏúºÎ°ú ÏûêÎ¶¨ Ïû°ÏïòÏ£†. NotebookLMÏùÄ ÏßÄÏãù Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Ïùò ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ ÏïåÏïÑÏÑú Ï≤òÎ¶¨Ìï¥Ï£ºÎ©¥ÏÑúÎèÑ, Í∑∏ Í≥ºÏ†ïÏùÄ Ïò§Î°ØÏù¥ Í∞úÏù∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ Í≤ΩÌóòÏúºÎ°ú ÎÇ®Í≤å Ìï¥Ï£ºÎäî Ï†ïÎßê Î©ãÏßÑ ÎèÑÍµ¨ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑêÎ°úÏÑú NotebookLMÏùÄ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò AI ÌååÌä∏ÎÑàÍ∞Ä ÎêòÏñ¥, ÏßÅÏ†ë Ï†úÍ≥µÌïú ÏûêÎ£åÏóêÏÑú ÌÜµÏ∞∞Î†•ÏùÑ ÎΩëÏïÑÎÇ¥Í≥†, Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Í∞úÎÖêÏùÑ Î™ÖÌôïÌûà ÏÑ§Î™ÖÌï¥Ï£ºÎ©∞, Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ ÏÑ±Ï∞∞ÍπåÏßÄ Ïú†ÎèÑÌï¥Ï§çÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Í±¥ Îã®ÏàúÌûà Ï†ÄÎÑêÎßÅÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥, ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Ï£ºÏ†úÎÇò ÏùµÏàôÌïú Ï£ºÏ†úÎ•º ÍπäÏù¥ ÏûàÍ≤å ÌÉêÏÉâÌïòÎäî ‘Í∞ÄÏù¥Îìú ÌÉêÌóò’Ïóê Í∞ÄÍπùÎã§Í≥† Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî. Ï†ïÎßêÏù¥ÏßÄ… Ïù¥Îü∞ Í≤ΩÌóòÏùÄ ÌùîÏπò ÏïäÏ£†.

Ïôú NotebookLMÏùÄ ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑêÎ°ú ÎπõÏùÑ Î∞úÌï†ÍπåÏöî?

Ï†úÍ∞Ä NotebookLMÏùÑ ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑêÎ°ú ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ¨Í≤å ÎäêÎÇÄ Ïû•Ï†êÏùÄ Î∞îÎ°ú ‘Ï†ëÏßÄÎêú Ï†ïÎ≥¥(Grounded Sources)’ÏôÄ ‘AIÏùò ÏÉÅÌò∏ÏûëÏö©’Ïù¥ ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïòÍ≤å Ï°∞ÌôîÎêúÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÎßéÏùÄ AI ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä Í∑∏Îü¥ÎìØÌïú ÎãµÎ≥ÄÏùÑ ÎÇ¥ÎÜìÏßÄÎßå, Ï∂úÏ≤òÍ∞Ä Î∂àÎ∂ÑÎ™ÖÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò ÎïåÎ°úÎäî 'ÌôòÍ∞Å(Hallucination)'ÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïù¥Í∏∞ÎèÑ ÌïòÏ£†. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå NotebookLMÏùÄ Ïò§ÏßÅ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏù¥ ÏóÖÎ°úÎìúÌïú ÏõêÎ≥∏ ÌååÏùºÏóêÏÑúÎßå Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Ï∂îÏ∂úÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Ï¶â, Î™®Îì† ÏöîÏïΩÏù¥ÎÇò ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏù¥ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò Ïã§Ï†ú ÏûêÎ£åÏóê Í∏∞Î∞òÏùÑ ÎëîÎã§Îäî ÏùòÎØ∏Ï£†. ÏùºÎ∞òÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÎãµÎ≥ÄÏù¥ÎÇò ÌãÄÎ¶∞ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Î∞õÏùÑ Í±±Ï†ï ÏóÜÏù¥, AIÍ∞Ä Ï†úÏãúÌïòÎäî Î™®Îì† ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÄ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏù¥ ÏùΩÏùÄ ÏûêÎ£å, Ïä¨ÎùºÏù¥Îìú, Í∞úÏù∏ Î©îÎ™®ÏôÄ Í∏¥Î∞ÄÌïòÍ≤å Ïó∞Í≤∞ÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

ÌïµÏã¨ Ìè¨Ïù∏Ìä∏: NotebookLMÏùÄ ÏóÖÎ°úÎìúÎêú ÏûêÎ£åÎ•º Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú ÏûëÎèôÌïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê, AIÏùò ÎãµÎ≥ÄÏù¥ Ìï≠ÏÉÅ Ï†ïÌôïÌïòÍ≥† Ïã†Î¢∞Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ‘ÌôòÍ∞Å’ ÌòÑÏÉÅÏúºÎ°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏûêÏú†Î°≠Îã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ Îß§Î†•Ïù¥Ï£†.

Ï†ÄÎäî Ï≤´ ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑê ÌîÑÎ°úÏ†ùÌä∏Î°ú “Ï∞ΩÏùòÏ†Å ÏÇ¨Í≥†(Creative Thinking)”ÎùºÎäî Ï£ºÏ†úÎ•º ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Ï£ºÏ†úÎäî ÌîÑÎ†àÏûÑÏõåÌÅ¨, Ïã¨Î¶¨Ìïô, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïã§Ïö©Ï†ÅÏù∏ Ïó∞Ïäµ Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÑ ÏïÑÏö∞Î•¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Îã§Î£®Í∏∞ÏóêÎèÑ Ï¢ãÏïòÏñ¥Ïöî. Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÎèÑ Í¥ÄÏã¨ ÏûàÎäî Ïñ¥Îñ§ Ï£ºÏ†úÎì† ÏÉÅÍ¥ÄÏóÜÏäµÎãàÎã§. NotebookLMÏùÄ Ïñ¥Îñ§ Ï£ºÏ†úÎì† ÏïÑÏù¥ÎîîÏñ¥ ÏπúÌôîÏ†ÅÏù∏ Í∏ÄÎ®∏Î¶¨ Í∏∞Ìò∏ÎÇò Ïã¨Ï∏µ Î≥¥Í≥†ÏÑúÎ°ú Î≥ÄÌôòÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÌïÑÏöîÌïú Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ ÏûòÎùºÎÇ¥Í≥† Ï°∞Ìï©ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÎÇòÎßåÏùò Î∞©ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú Ïû¨Íµ¨ÏÑ±Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏù¥ Ï†ïÎßê Ìé∏Î¶¨ÌñàÏñ¥Ïöî.

Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ï∏°Î©¥ ÏÇ¨Í≥†(lateral thinking), Ï†úÏïΩ Í∏∞Î∞ò Ï∞ΩÏùòÏÑ±(constraint-based creativity), Î∏åÎ†àÏù∏Ïä§ÌÜ†Î∞ç Î™®Îç∏Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú Ïó¨Îü¨ ÏïÑÌã∞ÌÅ¥ÏùÑ ÏóÖÎ°úÎìúÌñàÏùÑ Îïå, NotebookLMÏùÄ Î™á Î∂Ñ ÎßåÏóê ÌïµÏã¨ ÏöîÏ†êÎì§ÏùÑ Ìö®Í≥ºÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏóÆÏñ¥Ï£ºÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Îã®ÏàúÌûà ÏöîÏïΩÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥, Ï†ÄÎäî Ï†ÄÎßåÏùò Î©îÎ™®ÏôÄ ÏÑ±Ï∞∞ÏùÑ Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÍ≥†, Ïù¥Í≤ÉÏù¥ Î∞îÎ°ú Ï†ÄÎÑêÎßÅÏùò ÌïµÏã¨ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÎêú Î©îÎ™®Îì§ Ïó≠Ïãú Í∏∞Ï°¥ ÏûêÎ£åÎì§Í≥º Ïó∞Í≤∞ÎêòÎäî ‘ÏÜåÏä§’Í∞Ä Îê©ÎãàÎã§. ÌïôÏäµÌïòÎäî ÎèôÏïà Ï†ÄÎÑêÏù¥ Ïä§Ïä§Î°ú ÏóÖÎç∞Ïù¥Ìä∏ÎêòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Î≥¥Î©¥ÏÑú, ÏûêÎ£å Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÏôÄ Í∏∞Î°ùÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Î∂ÄÎã¥Ïù¥ Ìôï Ï§ÑÏñ¥ÎìúÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Î∞îÎ°ú ÎäêÎÅºÏã§ Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑ Í±∞ÏòàÏöî.

ÎÇòÎßåÏùò ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑê, Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÏÑ∏ÌåÖÌñàÎÇòÏöî?

NotebookLMÏùÑ ÌïôÏäµ Ï†ÄÎÑêÎ°ú Í∞ÄÏû• Ïú†Ïö©ÌïòÍ≤å ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÎäî Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÄ Í∞Å Ï£ºÏ†úÎßàÎã§ Î≥ÑÎèÑÏùò ÎÖ∏Ìä∏Î∂ÅÏùÑ ÎßåÎìúÎäî Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÌïòÎ©¥ AIÍ∞Ä Ïò¨Î∞îÎ•∏ ÏûêÎ£åÏóê ÏßëÏ§ëÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎèÑÎ°ù ÎèïÎäî Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Ï†ÄÎäî 'Ï∞ΩÏùòÏ†Å ÏÇ¨Í≥†' ÎÖ∏Ìä∏Î∂Å ÏïàÏóê Ïó∞Íµ¨ ÏûêÎ£å Ï°∞Í∞Å, Ï†ÄÏû•Ìï¥Îëî ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏, PDF Ï±ïÌÑ∞ Ïä§ÎÉÖÏÉ∑, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ïù¥Ï†ÑÏóê ÏûëÏÑ±ÌñàÎçò Î™áÎ™á Î©îÎ™®ÍπåÏßÄ Ï∞ΩÏùòÏÑ±Í≥º Í¥ÄÎ†®Îêú Î™®Îì† ÏûêÎ£åÎ•º ÏóÖÎ°úÎìúÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÌïòÎãà AIÍ∞Ä ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïú Í∏∞Î∞òÏùÑ Í∞ñÏ∂îÍ≤å ÎêòÏóàÍ≥†, AIÏùò Î™®Îì† ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏù¥ Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ï§ëÏöîÌïòÍ≤å Ïó¨Í∏∞Îäî ÏïÑÏù¥ÎîîÏñ¥Îì§Í≥º ÏùºÍ¥ÄÏÑ±ÏùÑ Ïú†ÏßÄÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ï†ïÎßêÏù¥ÏßÄ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏù¥ ÎÜÄÎùºÏõ†Ïñ¥Ïöî.

ÏßÑÏ†ïÌïú Ï†ÄÎÑêÎßÅÏùÄ Î∞îÎ°ú Ïù¥ ‘ÎÖ∏Ìä∏(Notes)’ ÏÑπÏÖòÏóêÏÑú ÏùºÏñ¥ÎÇ©ÎãàÎã§. NotebookLMÏù¥ Î™ÖÌôïÌïú ÏÑ§Î™ÖÏùÑ ÏÉùÏÑ±ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ÏóêÏÑú ÌÜµÏ∞∞Î†•ÏùÑ ÏñªÏùÑ ÎïåÎßàÎã§, Ï†ÄÎäî Í∑∏Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎÖ∏Ìä∏Î°ú Ï†ÄÏû•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. ÎòêÌïú, ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÎÖ∏Ìä∏Î•º Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÌïòÏó¨ Ï†ÄÎßåÏùò ÏÑ±Ï∞∞ÏùÑ Í∏∞Î°ùÌïòÍ≥† ÏõêÌïòÎäî ÌòïÏãùÏúºÎ°ú Ìé∏ÏßëÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî. ÎïåÎ°úÎäî Ï†úÍ∞Ä Î∞∞Ïö¥ Í≤ÉÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÌïúÎëê Ï§ÑÏùò ÏßßÏùÄ Î¨∏Ïû•Ïù¥ Îê† ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÍ≥†, Îã§Î•∏ ÎïåÏóêÎäî Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÍπäÏù¥ Í≥†ÎØºÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÏßàÎ¨∏Ïù¥ ÎêòÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÌïòÏ£†.

ÌåÅ: Îã®ÏàúÌûà ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÎÖ∏Ìä∏ Ïô∏ÏóêÎèÑ, NotebookLMÏùÄ Î≥¥Í≥†ÏÑú, ÌïôÏäµ Í∞ÄÏù¥Îìú, ÎßàÏù∏ÎìúÎßµ, Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ Ïò§ÎîîÏò§ ÌåüÏ∫êÏä§Ìä∏ÍπåÏßÄ Ï†ÄÎÑêÏùò ÏùºÎ∂ÄÎ°ú Ìè¨Ìï®ÏãúÌÇ¨ Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Îã§ÏñëÌïú ÌòïÏãùÏúºÎ°ú ÌïôÏäµ Í≥ºÏ†ïÏùÑ ÌíçÎ∂ÄÌïòÍ≤å Í∏∞Î°ùÌï¥Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî!

Íæ∏Ï§ÄÌïú NotebookLM Ïó∞Íµ¨ Î∞è ÌïôÏäµ ÏõåÌÅ¨ÌîåÎ°úÏö∞Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Ïù¥ ÎèÑÍµ¨Îäî Ï†ÄÏùò Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ ÏïÑÏù¥ÎîîÏñ¥Îì§ÏùÑ Îã¥ÏïÑÎÇ¥Îäî ÏÑ±Ïû•ÌïòÎäî Î†àÌçºÎü∞Ïä§ ÎùºÏù¥Î∏åÎü¨Î¶¨Î°ú Îπ†Î•¥Í≤å Î≥ÄÎ™®ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. posts.content:encodedSnippet:
ÏûëÎÖÑ Ïó∞ÎßêÏóê Îî∞ÎúªÌïú Î∞©ÏΩïÏóêÏÑú Î©∞Ïπ† ÎèôÏïà Ìú¥ÏãùÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏ°åÎã§. ÎßêÏù¥ Ìú¥ÏãùÏù¥ÏßÄÎßå, Ïö∞Î¶∞ ÏõåÎÇô Ï†ÅÏùÄ Ïù∏Î†•Ïù¥ ÎßéÏùÄ ÏùºÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥†, Í∞ÅÏûê Îß°ÏùÄ ÏùºÏù¥ ÏûàÏñ¥ÏÑú ÏùºÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ïâ¨Îäî ÏùºÏ†ïÏù¥ÏóàÎäîÎç∞, ÏùºÎ≥¥Îã§Îäî Ìú¥ÏãùÏùÑ Îçî ÎßéÏù¥ ÌïòÎ†§Í≥† ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌñàÎã§.
Ïù¥ Í∏∞Í∞ÑÏóê Í≥®ÌîÑÎ•º Î™á Î≤à Ï≥§ÎäîÎç∞, Í≥®ÌîÑ ÎùºÏö¥Îî©Ïù¥ ÎÅùÎÇòÍ≥† Ï†êÏàòÌëúÎ•º Î≥¥Î©¥ Îß§Î≤à Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏïÑÏâ¨ÏõÄÏùò ÎßêÎì§ÏùÑ ÌñàÎã§. ‚Äú1Î≤à ÌôÄ Ìåå 5ÏóêÏÑú Î¨ºÏóê Îëê Î≤à Îπ†Ï†∏ÏÑú 4Ïò§Î≤ÑÎßå Ïïà ÌñàÎã§Î©¥ 80ÎåÄ Ï≥§ÏùÑ ÌÖêÎç∞.‚Äù , ‚Äú13Î≤à ÌôÄÏóêÏÑú ÌçºÌåÖÏùÑ Îëê Í∞úÎ°ú ÎÅùÎÉàÎã§Î©¥ Í∑∏ ÌôÄÏùÄ ÌååÌñàÏùÑ ÌÖêÎç∞. Ïò§Îäò ÌçºÌåÖÏù¥ Î≥ÑÎ°úÎÑ§.‚Äù , ‚ÄúÏïÑÏù¥Ïñ∏ÏùÄ ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌñàÎäîÎç∞ ÎìúÎùºÏù¥Î≤ÑÍ∞Ä Ïò§Îäò ÌòëÏ°∞Î•º Ïïà Ìï¥Ï£ºÎÑ§.‚Äù
Ïù¥ÌõÑ ÏàôÏÜåÎ°ú ÎèåÏïÑÏôÄÏÑú Îã§Ïãú ÏóÖÎ¨¥Î•º Ï≤òÎ¶¨ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Î™áÎ™á Ìà¨ÏûêÏÇ¨ ÎåÄÌëúÎãòÎì§Í≥º Ïù¥Î©îÏùº, Ïπ¥ÌÜ°, ÌÜµÌôîÎ•º ÌñàÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎßêÎì§ÏùÑ ÌñàÎã§. ‚ÄúÏïÑÏâΩÎÑ§Ïöî. Îü∞Ïõ®Ïù¥Í∞Ä 3Í∞úÏõîÎßå Îçî ÏûàÏóàÎã§Î©¥ ÏûòÌñàÏùÑ ÌÖêÎç∞Ïöî.‚Äù , ‚ÄúÍ∑∏Îïå Í∑∏ Ìà¨ÏûêÍ∞Ä ÎêêÏñ¥Ïïº ÌïòÎäîÎç∞‚Äù , ‚ÄúÍµ≥Ïù¥ Í∑∏ Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÎäîÎç∞ ÏãúÍ∞Ñ, ÏÇ¨Îûå, ÎèàÏùÑ Í∑∏Îïå Ïïà Ïç®Ïïº ÌñàÎäîÎç∞‚Äù , ‚ÄúÍ∑∏Îïå Í∑∏ Ï†ïÎèÑÏùò Îß§Ï∂úÏùÑ Ìï¥Ïïº ÌñàÎäîÎç∞‚Äù
Ïã§ÏùÄ ÏúÑÏóêÏÑú Ïö∞Î¶¨ Ìà¨ÏûêÏÇ¨ ÎåÄÌëúÎì§Ïù¥ ÌïòÎäî ÎßêÏùÄ 1ÎÖÑ ÎÇ¥ÎÇ¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎßéÏù¥ Îì£Îäî ÎßêÏù¥Í≥†, Îì§ÏùÑ ÎïåÎßàÎã§ ÎÇòÎèÑ Í∞ôÏù¥ ÏïÑÏâ¨ÏõåÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥ÎÇ†ÏùÄ ÎåÄÌëúÎãòÎì§Ïùò ÏïÑÏâ¨ÏõÄÍ≥º Ïò§Ï†ÑÏùò ÎÇ¥ Í≥®ÌîÑ ÎùºÏö¥Îî©Ïùò ÏïÑÏâ¨ÏõÄÏù¥ Î®∏Î¶øÏÜçÏóêÏÑú Í≤πÏπòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ìïú Í∞ÄÏßÄÏùò ÏûëÏùÄ Íπ®Îã¨ÏùåÍ≥º Î∞∞ÏõÄÏù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Í∑∏Í±¥ Î∞îÎ°ú Ïù¥Í≤å Ïù∏ÏÉùÏù¥Í≥†, Ïù∏ÏÉùÏóêÏÑú ‚ÄòÍ∑∏Îïå‚ÄôÎäî Îã§Ïãú Ïò§ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Í∑∏Îïå, ÎòêÎäî ÏßÄÍ∏à Î¨¥Ï°∞Í±¥ ÏµúÏÑ†ÏùÑ Îã§Ìï¥ÏÑú ÏûòÌï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Í∑∏ ÏàúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏßÄÎÇ¨Îã§Î©¥, Í≤∞Í≥ºÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Îã§ÏãúÎäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥†, Î∂àÌèâÌïòÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÍ≥†, ÏïÑÏâ¨ÏõåÌïòÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÍ≥†, Í∑∏ÎÉ• Î∞îÎ°ú Îã§Ïùå ÏàòÎ•º ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÍ≥† Í±∞Í∏∞Ïóê ÏßëÏ§ëÌï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏù¥Îã§.
ÎÇ¥ Í≥®ÌîÑ ÎùºÏö¥Îî©ÏóêÏÑú Í≥µÏù¥ Î¨ºÏóê Îπ†ÏßÄÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§Î©¥, Î™®Îì† ÌçºÌåÖÏùÑ ÏÑ∏ Í∞ú ÎåÄÏã† Îëê Í∞úÎ°ú ÎßàÎ¨¥Î¶¨ÌñàÎã§Î©¥, Í∑∏ Ïπ©ÏÉ∑ÏùÑ ÏÇêÏßÅÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÎã§Î©¥,,,Í∑∏Îü¨Î©¥ ÎãπÏó∞Ìûà Ï†êÏàòÍ∞Ä Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îçî Ï¢ãÏïòÏùÑ Í≤ÉÏù¥Í≥†, ÏµúÍ≥†Ïùò Í≥®ÌîÑ Í≤ΩÍ∏∞Î•º ÌñàÏùÑ ÌÖêÎç∞. Ïù¥Îü∞ ÌõÑÌöåÎäî ÏãúÍ∞Ñ ÎÇ≠ÎπÑÎã§. Í∑∏Îïå Ìã∞Î∞ïÏä§Ïóê Ïò¨ÎûêÏùÑ Îïå, Í∑∏Î¶∞ ÏúÑÏóê ÏûàÏùÑ Îïå, Í∑∏Îïå ÎÇòÎäî Ï†ïÏã† Ï∞®Î¶¨Í≥† Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Ìï¥Ïïº ÌñàÎã§. ÏôúÎÉêÌïòÎ©¥ Í∏∞ÌöåÎùºÎäî Í±¥ Ïó¨Îü¨ Î≤à Ïò§ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥†, Îã§ÏãúÎäî ‚ÄòÍ∑∏Îïå‚ÄôÍ∞Ä Ïò§ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.
Îü∞Ïõ®Ïù¥Í∞Ä 3Í∞úÏõîÎßå Îçî ÏûàÏóàÎã§Î©¥ ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Ï∂úÏãúÌï¥ÏÑú ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º ÌùëÏûêÏ†ÑÌôò ÏãúÏº∞ÏùÑ ÌÖêÎç∞, ÏïÑÏâΩÏßÄÎßå, ÏßÄÍ∏àÏùÄ Îü∞Ïõ®Ïù¥Í∞Ä ÎÅùÎÇ¨Îã§. Î™á Îã¨ Ï†ÑÏóê Îü∞Ïõ®Ïù¥Í∞Ä ÎÇ®ÏïÑ ÏûàÏùÑ Îïå, Í∑∏Îïå Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Ïûò Ìï¥Ïïº ÌñàÎã§. posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Ïù¥ Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ÏÑúÎèÑ Î™á Î≤à Ïù∏Ïö©ÌñàÎäîÎç∞, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏßÄÎÇú 2ÎÖÑ ÎèôÏïà Í∞ÄÏû• ÎßéÏù¥ Î∞òÎ≥µÌï¥ÏÑú ÏùΩÍ≥† ÏçºÎçò Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏãúÍ∞Ä ÏûàÎã§.
‚ÄúÏïÑÏ£º ÏûëÏùÄ ÏùºÏù¥ÎùºÎèÑ
ÏùºÏ£ºÏùºÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜçÌïòÎ©¥ ÏÑ±Ïã§Ìïú Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§.
Ìïú Îã¨ÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜç ÌïúÎã§Î©¥ Ïã†ÏùòÍ∞Ä ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§.
Ïùº ÎÖÑÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜç ÌïúÎã§Î©¥ ÏÉùÌôúÏù¥ Î≥ÄÌï† Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§.
Ïã≠ ÎÖÑÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜç ÌïúÎã§Î©¥ Ïù∏ÏÉùÏù¥ Î∞îÎÄî Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§.
ÏÑ∏ÏÉÅÏùò Î™®Îì† ÌÅ∞ Ïùº
ÏïÑÏ£º ÏûëÏùÄ ÏùºÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜç ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏóêÏÑú ÏãúÏûëÎê©ÎãàÎã§.‚Äù
Í∞ïÎØ∏Ï†ï ÏûëÍ∞ÄÏùò ‚ÄòÏïÑÏ£º ÏûëÏùÄ Ïùº‚ÄôÏù¥ÎùºÎäî ÏãúÏù∏Îç∞, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏÇ¥Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏÇ¥Î†§Í≥† ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÎäî ÏÇ∂ÏùÑ Ïûò ÏïïÏ∂ïÌïú Î™á Ï§ÑÏùò Î¨∏Ïû•Ïù¥Îã§. Î≠îÍ∞Ä ÏùºÏù¥ Ïûò Ïïà ÌíÄÎ¶¥ ÎïåÎßàÎã§ ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏùΩÍ≥† Ïì∞Í∏∞Î•º Î∞òÎ≥µÌïòÎäî Ï£ºÏò•Í∞ôÏùÄ ÏãúÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§.
Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎßàÏùåÍ∞ÄÏßêÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÄÎ†§Í≥† ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÎäî ÏôÄÏ§ë, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏûêÏ£º Îì£Îäî Ï†ÑÏßÅ ÌäπÏàòÎ∂ÄÎåÄÏõêÏùò ÌåüÏ∫êÏä§Ìä∏(Jocko Podcast) Ïù∏ÌÑ∞Î∑∞ÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥Îñ§ Íµ∞Ïù∏Ïù¥ Î≥∏Ïù∏Ïùò Ïù∏ÏÉùÏ≤†ÌïôÏùÄ ‚Äúbe big in the little things‚ÄùÎùºÎäî ÎßêÏùÑ ÌñàÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥ Îßê ÎòêÌïú ÎÇ¥ ÎßàÏùåÍ∞ÄÏßêÏùÑ ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïòÍ≤å Ï†ïÎ¶¨Ìï¥ Ï£ºÎäî Ï£ºÏò•Í∞ôÏùÄ Îã®Ïñ¥Îì§Ïù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§.
ÎßéÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ ÏÉàÌï¥Î•º ÎßûÏù¥ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Îã§ÏßêÍ≥º Í≤∞Ïã¨ÏùÑ ÌïúÎã§. ÎÇòÎäî ÏÉàÌï¥ Îã§ÏßêÏùÄ ÏóÜÍ≥† Í∑∏ÎÉ• Ïù∏ÏÉù Îã§ÏßêÎßå ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Îß§ÎÖÑ 1Ïõî 1Ïùº ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ ÎåÄÎã®Ìïú Îã§ÏßêÎì§ÏùÑ ÌïúÎã§. ÏïÑÏ£º Í±∞Ï∞ΩÌïòÍ≥† Í±∞ÎåÄÌïú Îã§ÏßêÎì§Ïù∏Îç∞, Ïù¥Îü∞ Í±∞Ï∞ΩÌïú Îã§ÏßêÏùÑ ÌïòÎäî Î∂Ñ Ï§ë Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú Ïã§ÌñâÌïòÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§ÏùÄ Îã® Ìïú Î™ÖÎèÑ ÏóÜÏóàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü∞ Î∂ÑÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å ÎÇòÎäî ÏïûÏúºÎ°úÎäî ‚ÄúÏûëÏùÄ ÏùºÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Ìï¥Îùº(be big in the little things)‚ÄùÎùºÍ≥† ÎßêÌï¥Ï§Ñ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.
ÏÉàÌï¥Í∞Ä ÎêòÎ©¥ Îòê Ìó¨Ïä§Ïû•Ïóê Ïù∏Í∞ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Î∞îÍ∏ÄÎ∞îÍ∏ÄÌï† Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Î©∞Ïπ† Ï†ÑÏóê ÏπúÍµ¨Í∞Ä ‚ÄúÏÉàÌï¥Í∞Ä ÎêòÎ©¥ Íº≠ Ïö¥Îèô ÎÅäÏñ¥ÏÑú ÏùºÏ£ºÏùºÏóê ÏµúÏÜå 4Î≤àÏùÄ Ìó¨Ïä§Ïû• Í∞ÄÏïºÏßÄ‚ÄùÎùºÍ≥† ÌñàÎäîÎç∞, ÎÇòÎäî Ïù¥ ÏπúÍµ¨ÏóêÍ≤å Í∑∏Îü¨ÏßÄ ÎßêÍ≥†, Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÏßÄÍ∏à ÎãπÏû• Îì±Î°ùÌï¥ÏÑú Ïò§ÎäòÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Î∞îÎ°ú ÏãúÏûëÌïòÎùºÍ≥† ÌñàÎã§. Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å Í±∞Ï∞ΩÌïòÍ≤å Ïã†ÎÖÑÏóê Ïó¥Ïã¨Ìûà Ïö¥ÎèôÌïòÍ≤†Îã§Í≥† Í≤∞Ïã¨Ìï† ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏóê Í∑∏ÎÉ• Ïò§Îäò ÎãπÏû• Í∞ÄÏÑú Ïö¥Îèô ÏãúÏûëÌïòÎäî Í≤å Îçî Ïâ¨Ïö¥ ÏùºÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ìó¨Ïä§Ïû• Îì±Î°ùÌï† ÌïÑÏöîÎèÑ ÏóÜÍ≥† Í∑∏ÎÉ• Îß§Ïùº Ïä§ÏøºÌä∏ ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏñëÏπòÌïòÍ≥†, ÏñëÏπò ÎÅùÎÇòÍ≥† Ìë∏Ïâ¨ÏóÖ 5Í∞úÏî©Îßå ÌïòÎ©¥ ÎêúÎã§. ÏûëÏùÄ Í≤ÉÏóêÏÑú ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌï®ÏùÑ Ï∂îÍµ¨ÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥ ÏûëÏùÄ ÏùºÏùÑ Í≥ÑÏÜçÌïòÎ©¥ ÏïÑÏ£º ÌÅ∞ ÏùºÏù¥ ÎêòÎäîÎç∞, Ï≤òÏùåÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÌÅ∞ ÏùºÏùÑ ÌïòÎ†§Í≥† ÌïòÎ©¥ Ïûò ÏïàÎêúÎã§.
ÏûëÏùÄ ÏùºÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú ÌïòÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ ÌÅ∞ ÏùºÎèÑ ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïòÍ≤å ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ÎÇòÎäî Ïù¥Í±∏ Îß§Îã¨ ÏõîÎßêÏóê Í≤ΩÌóòÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Î™®Îì† Ìè¨Ìä∏Ìè¥Î¶¨Ïò§ÏÇ¨ ÎåÄÌëúÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å Îß§Îã¨ ÏóÖÎç∞Ïù¥Ìä∏Î•º Í≥µÏú†Ìï¥Îã¨ÎùºÍ≥† ÌïúÎã§. Î≠ê, Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å ÎåÄÎã®Ìïú ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ ÏöîÍµ¨ÌïòÎäî Í±¥ ÏïÑÎãàÍ≥†, ÏõîÍ∞Ñ Î¶¨Ìè¨Ìä∏Î•º ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑú ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ Ìï†Ïï†ÌïòÎùºÍ≥† ÌïòÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÎäîÎã§. Ïñ¥Ï∞®Ìîº ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥Î©¥ Îß§Îã¨ Ï†ïÍ∏∞Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖ ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûòÌïú Í≤ÉÍ≥º Î™ª Ìïú Í≤ÉÏùÑ Î≥µÍ∏∞ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ï°∞Í∏àÏî© Îçî Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§Í∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑú ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïúÎã§. ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎã§ Î≥¥Î©¥ Ïò®Í∞ñ Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄÏù¥ Îã•ÏπòÎäîÎç∞, ÏõîÍ∞Ñ ÏóÖÎç∞Ïù¥Ìä∏Î•º Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÎì§Í≥º Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÎäî Í±¥ Ï†ïÎßê ÏûëÏùÄ Ïùº Ï§ëÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ Í∞ÄÏû• ÏûëÏùÄ ÏùºÏù¥Îã§.
ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥ ÏûëÏùÄ ÏùºÎèÑ Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Î™ª ÌïòÎäî ÎåÄÌëúÎì§Ïù¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎßéÎã§. Ìïú Îã¨Ïóê Ìïú Î≤à, Ïõî ÎßàÍ∞êÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÏôÄÏùò ÏµúÏÜåÌïúÏùò ÏïΩÏÜçÏù¥Ïûê ÏòàÏùòÏù∏ Í∞ÑÎûµÌïú Î¶¨Ìè¨ÌåÖÎèÑ Î™ª ÌïòÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Î¨¥Ïä® ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥†, ÌéÄÎìúÎ†àÏù¥ÏßïÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥†, ÏòÅÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥†, Ï±ÑÏö©ÏùÑ Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú ÌïòÍ≤†Îã§Í≥† ÌïòÎäîÏßÄ Í∞ÄÎÅîÏùÄ Ïù¥Ìï¥Ìï† ÏàòÍ∞Ä ÏóÜÎã§. Ïù¥Îü∞ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïùò ÌäπÏßï Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÍ∞Ä Ìï≠ÏÉÅ ÌÅ∞ Ìïú Î∞©ÏùÑ ÎÖ∏Î¶¨Í≥†, ÌÅ∞ ÏùºÏùÑ ÌïòÎ†§Í≥† ÌïòÎäîÎç∞, Í∑∏ Ï†ÑÏóê ÏûëÏùÄ Í≤ÉÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïòÍ≤å ÌïòÎùºÍ≥† Ï°∞Ïñ∏ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂Îã§.
ÏûëÍ≥† ÏÇ¨ÏÜåÌïú Í≤ÉÏóêÏÑú ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌï®Í≥º ÏúÑÎåÄÌï®ÏùÑ Ï∂îÍµ¨Ìï¥Îùº. Í∑∏Îü¨Î©¥ ÌÅ¨Í≥† ÏõêÎåÄÌïú Í≤ÉÏùÄ ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å Îî∞ÎùºÏò®Îã§.
